title-group.article-title: Students as expert witnesses of teaching and learning

bio.title: Biography
bio.p: Hugh Busher is a Senior Lecturer and researcher at the School of Education, University of Leicester, where he teaches to Masters and Doctoral students research methods, critical perspectives of the interactions of people, power and culture in mainly school-based communities and the conflicts surrounding students’ and teachers’ voices in particular policy contexts. In 2009 he co-authored Online Interviewing with Sage.

article-meta.issue-title: The Space Between - Positioning Student Voice at the heart of Leadership in Education

abstract.p: Student voice is a key component in constructing discourses of respect, empowerment and citizenship in schools. It can help schools to become learning communities, rather than knowledge factories, that serve the needs of the majority of their members, the students, as successfully as possible and prepare them for future lives in a wide variety of contexts. It can help to improve pedagogical and organisational practice. This article takes the position that students are expert observers of school life and teachers’ practices and interrogates what they consider to be more and less successful approaches to those. It draws on three studies of student voices that were carried out by the author with colleagues between 2006 and 2011 in England and Lebanon in primary and secondary schools.

sec.title: Introduction
sec.p: This article interrogates students’ voices in predominantly intercultural contexts on more and less successful approaches to teaching, learning and leadership in schools, including what relationships between teachers and students might construct cultures in schools and classrooms that facilitate learning. The article draws on three empirical studies of students’ perspectives on schooling carried out by the author and colleagues, one of which was based in four charity foundation primary schools in Beirut, Lebanon (Nabhani et al., 2012) serving economically disadvantaged city communities. The second study was of Year 9 (Y9, 13−14 year old) students of English in a state secondary school in England (Cremin et al., 2011) serving a mixed multi-cultural catchment area of private and social housing. The third was of Y9 Science students (Tas and Busher, 2011) in two state secondary schools in England, one serving a largely mono-cultural rural area and one an urban multi-cultural but largely economically disadvantaged area. The three studies varied in size, but none had fewer than 30 participants and all used semi-structured interviews with students and teachers, as well as non-participant observation by researchers as the main data-collection instruments.

Accessing students’ perspectives on education used to be encouraged by central government in England because it promoted personalised learning (DfES, 2008) and recognised students as clients of a school who had a right to be heard in the evaluation of schools (Troman et al., 2007). Accessing students’ voices encourages student engagement in learning by giving them a sense of ownership of the process and of the school institutions in which their work is located (Riley and Rustique-Forrester, 2002; Potter, 2002; Sebba and Robinson, 2011). Consequently, it helps to develop a more inclusive school environment (Demetriou and Wilson, 2010). It also helps teachers to reflect more critically on their practices to improve the quality of schooling, teaching and learning (McIntyre et al., 2005). Interaction with others and iterative identity construction (Giddens, 1991) are central theoretical constructs in people’s self-development, of which learning forms a part.

Listening to students’ voices acknowledges the rights of students to influence the shaping of their own learning (Fielding, 2004) and the processes of their school organisation, democratising schooling (Flutter and Rudduck, 2004). It recognises that students are citizens, not merely citizens in preparation, whose rights should be respected in the present as well as in the future. It forms part of the enactment of children’s rights under the UN Convention of the Rights of the Child (UNCRC) (Sebba and Robinson, 2011). Within the European Union, the development of citizenship by member states is recognised as crucial to the construction of society (Osler and Starkey, 1999). However, there are some distinct national differences in understandings of citizenship, with an emphasis on ‘active citizenship’ in England, highlighting citizens’ duties and responsibilities rather than their rights (Ross, 2003) but on instrumental citizen rights (e.g. the right to travel, or to work) in France and Spain (Edye, 2003).

Further, the concept of student voice is itself problematic. Some views hold that it can only be articulated when teachers authorise it and usually in ways that curtail any critical discussion of prevailing conditions (Ruddock, 2006). Other views assume that student voice is monolingual (Robinson and Taylor, 2007), speaking only in the particular ways expected of subordinates by ruling elites (Spivak, in Morton, 2002), in the case of schools, the teachers, denying the multi-faceted nature of student perspectives (Rubin and Silva, 2003).

School processes often serve to disempower students. In England, it is difficult to promote a genuinely democratic dialogue in schools (Arnot and Reay 2007) because state schools try to optimise their own performance within the disciplinary framework of performative education policy (Troman et al., 2007). ‘The structures of secondary schooling offer, on the whole, less responsibility and autonomy than many young people are accustomed to taking out of school’ (Flutter and Rudduck, 2004, p.1). Further, student ‘consultation’, when it occurs, may be tokenistic (Byrom et al., 2007) because of the policy contexts of schooling, the fear of some senior staff of ‘losing control’ (Busher and Cremin, 2012), and an unwillingness of teachers to recognise the legitimacy of different, including students’, perspectives on schooling (Robinson and Taylor, 2007) and the intersectionality of gender, social status, ethnicity and faith (Reay, 2006) in the construction of student perspectives: there is not one student voice to be heard but many, and they may differ from the (multiplicity of) teachers’ voices.

However, involving students directly in school decision-making about issues of immediate relevance to their own lives, such as teaching, learning and school organisation, helps to develop their sense of citizenship by constructing respectful cultures in schools (Sebba and Robinson, 2011) and raises their general levels of motivation and productivity (Potter, 2002; Clough and Holden, 2002) by giving them a sense of ownership of school processes, including what happens in lessons and classrooms. It helps students to perceive themselves as members of a community of learners (Rudduck and McIntyre, 2007) who help to shape its practices rather than being workers in a knowledge factory. This helps teachers and schools to meet students’ educational needs more successfully, especially in schools serving economically and socially disadvantaged areas (Fielding, 2004; Mujis et al., 2005).

None the less, in England in the early 21st century education lagged behind some other child services in terms of heeding what children had to say (Hancock and Mansfield, 2002). For example, the agenda of school councils were often dominated by the agenda of senior staff (Fielding, 2004) or students were limited to discussing matters that senior staff considered appropriate to them, such as bullying policy (Busher and Cremin, 2012).

Students are experienced participant observers of teachers, teaching and schools (Riley and Rustique-Forrester, 2002). Many are able to articulate clearly what they consider to be effective and ineffective teaching and support for students, expressing views that chime closely with the literature on effective teaching (Wragg et al., 2000; Cooper et al., 2000). Encouraging students to speak out about matters that concern them in school, whether in playgrounds, corridors, classrooms or lessons, helps teachers to see the school world through the eyes of the main actors in school and adapt their practices accordingly, albeit within the contexts of internal and external school policy discourses and teachers’ own value-laden perspectives of practice.

sec.title: Students’ views on teacher−student relationships
sec.p: Students in all three studies were asked about what they enjoyed about schooling and indicated that they enjoyed similar aspects (Tables 1, 2, 3), such as being with their friends, having exciting resources to support the curriculum and having competent teachers. Students also recognised the importance of having positive relationships with teachers to help them learn.

caption.p: Lebanese primary school students’ views of what they liked about schooling

tr.td: The teachers, recess, sports, art, writing, French, math, fun in class, studying, playing with friends, amusement, preparation for the future, learning new things, sports, trips, theatre, technology and computer, my friends.

caption.p: Year 9 English students’ views of what they like about schooling

list-item.p: Competent teachers: know what we’re doing … if [pupils]’re not do[ing] their work, they can tell them off … they help you [I got] a level 7 in my mock SATs
Respectful relationships: there’s always a nice atmosphere … she’s always really happy and really nice about things and you.
Being with friends: It’s … where you’ve got all your friends and get along with loads of people … exciting
Good facilities / resources: It’s a big sports hall [and] pretty good and you can sometimes go after school
This is the DT block … and we’ve got good equipment and everything.

caption.p: Year 9 Science students’ views of what they like about schooling

list-item.p: friends and socialising: enjoy myself more when I have friends in lessons that I can share ideas with
learning new and interesting things: the challenge of learning new things; learning things I wouldn’t find out about anywhere else
relationships with teachers: some teachers are ok
friends and socialising: meeting friends; friendly atmosphere
learning new and interesting things: In (mentioned) subjects; extracurricular
relationships with teachers: teachers explain things thoroughly
ways of learning: interactive ways teachers present; very useful to gain important skills such as communication skills and a lot of confidence; independent study

sec.p: Students liked those teachers who acknowledged their agency and constructed respectful relationships with them as well as making learning exciting. Such views offer important clues to school leaders whether at school, department or classroom level, about what organisational cultures are likely to help students to engage strongly with schooling.

A closer investigation of students’ perspectives on successful relationships with teachers showed considerable commonality with what is known about collaborative relationships between leaders and followers that help to create school development (Muijs et al., 2005; Stoll and Seashore Louis, 2007). Students had clear ideas about the quality of relationships with teachers that helped them to learn, as is shown in Tables 4 and 5. These included qualities of respect and trust, care and concern, and maintaining order so that students could work purposefully. The English students recognised that teachers needed to sustain a school’s system (Table 4), indeed some welcomed their gentle surveillance during recreation times, but preferred to work in a relaxed atmosphere where they felt respected.

caption.p: Year 9 English students’ views of creating a culture of engagement

list-item.p: [good teachers] … let you sit with your friends and get on with your work, and they’re not always telling you off and [like] give you detention for no reason
The teacher … makes you laugh. So it’s quite a nice atmosphere again
In some lessons you can just chill out and do your work and talk … it helps me concentrate
and she’s really funny, so basically we can do our work and have a laugh at the same time.
everyone has a named teacher, or a tutor … if there’s anything you want to talk about, they’ll ask you to see if you’re alright … and then they’ll go to the Deputy Head
our area where we hang around … staff are there to keep an eye on you … just in case something does happen
I did really well in my Maths test the other day. I was really proud of myself. Miss [name] helping me loads of times
[Learning Support staff] sits next to me – all lessons. Me and her get on very well … she’s nice
teachers that are quite strict and they want you to do the work – because they want us to get good grades
the good thing about that is we have teachers that walk around the field to check if anybody is [smoking]

caption.p: Year 9 Science students’ views of creating cultures of engagement

list-item.p: how teachers support/treat us: always try their hardest to help me to learn / get the grades I want; They treat us responsibly, and speak to us clearly; they are nice

teachers encouragement and enthusiasm: my biology teacher is good at teaching and gets along with you; They are funny and jolly; but get through the work and don't take things too far or let students get carried away
how teachers support/treat us: we can go to any preferred teacher and ask for help
teachers encouragement and enthusiasm: gives us continuous encouragement and rewards us for achievements; they motivate us to work harder and they believe in us
time /availability: willing to spend breaks and lunches to help us secure and pass our grades; making time for us whenever needed
teachers control: she can control the class

sec.p: Science students echoed these views (Table 5), claiming that supportive relationships with teachers included being able to talk with their teachers about their work when they needed to. They were grateful for teachers and support staff who took an interest in them and their work, kept them safe and controlled the classes so they could work. Science students also emphasised the importance of teachers’ enthusiasm for their subject. Students in the Lebanese schools (Table 1) also thought it important to have support from teachers and clear explanations to help them with their work.

Such views expressed by students resonate strongly with research on constructing learning communities, whether amongst staff or with students (Bolam et al., 2005; Busher et al, 2007), and the importance of leaders working with other members of such communities to create cultures of collaboration that further the purposes of the community in its policy contexts. They also resonate positively with the views expressed by Lebanese teachers on how they helped students to engage with the curriculum (Table 6). The fictitious acronyms in Table 6 indicate schools in the Lebanese study. This suggests that the construction of purposeful learning communities can take place by leaders at many levels in a school: whole school, subject or key stage area, or classroom, whatever operational unit of a school organisation is being considered. Wenger (1998) makes the same point. But it does suggest that leadership and the projection of power to enact, emblematise and sustain particular values is an important element in the construction of organisational cultures (Busher et al., 2007).

caption.p: Lebanese teachers’ views: Creating enthusiastic and engaged learners

tr.td: ( AK Teachers ) teacher act as a guide … show interest and listen to students’ problems … help [students] solve [learning problems] … encourage them … to have self-confidence … and show their new capabilities … establish integration between subjects so there is not extensive repetition … use cooperative learning … do many activities outside the class … build social skills like respecting others and appreciating them … give equal chances to all students

( ABAM Teachers ) Use interactive tasks to engage children … reward good behaviour, good performance and good manners … [children want] positive praise and feedback … observe and evaluate students’ work and behaviour … follow up to ensure successful work … give frequent guidance … create interest in the subject/ topic … build [children's] confidence and strong personality.

( HS Teachers ) show the relevance of learning to [students'] everyday lives … be interested in how children develop [work] at home … get students to create the school calendar (pictures and text) … place [children] at the centre of the teaching/learning process … make students feel important about what they are doing … students encouraged [required] to make presentations of stories / projects to their classes … support low achieving students to do well at something (e.g. with theatre / dance) … offer remedial work after formal assessments … help students recognise the steps in their own learning processes.

sec.title: Students’ views on successful lessons
sec.p: At a classroom level teachers have a major responsibility as leaders (Bourdieu and Passeron, 1977) to ensure that learning takes place successfully, not only to meet the performance targets of a school, but also to help students develop a range of knowledge and skills that contribute to their cultural capital (Bourdieu, 1986) and life opportunities after school. Students’ views on how successful lessons can be constituted offer teachers important perspectives to help them shape their teaching (McIntyre et al., 2005). They also offer senior and middle staff important insights for shaping professional development programmes for teachers and support staff.

Students in these studies focused on the cultures that were constructed in lessons, on the leadership that teachers constructed with students and on the pedagogical strategies teachers used with the resources they had available to them. Important among the pedagogical strategies were practical work, learning related to students everyday lives where possible, work that challenged students’ capabilities and met their own idiosyncratic preferences for learning (Tables 7 and 8).

caption.p: Year 9 English students’ views of successful lessons

list-item.p: Styles of learning: To have more [like] hands-on things, rather than just listening or watching someone do it - you [like] do it for yourself … in my ICT I’m … making videos. We’ve got to make downloadable tunes advert
Use of resources: So I’m not very keen on it … I [like] using the interactive boards more, really … making it more interesting … Make things really colourful and bright

Relevant to everyday life: Cooking is something you need to know 'cos you can’t just … order takeaways all the time … in IT you get to learn a lot about computers, technology, even about what’s happening around the world
Practical work: I only like science when we’re, like, doing experiments or, like, when we’re writing out conclusions

caption.p: Year 9 Science students’ views of successful lessons

list-item.p: Practicals: use experiments to get across the point;
Explanations: [Teachers] are very clear, how they talk/explain to the class; not too complicated
Group / interactive activities: it is really interesting to see people's ideas about topics
Fun: [teachers] try and make the lessons as fun as possible
Practicals: help us to visualise concepts; I prefer doing things with my hands
Explanations: she explains things to us in an understandable way
Teaching and learning resources: they provide us with resources that can help to boost our grades
Group / interactive activities: we get to share our ideas with other classmates; fun: make the lessons fun so they’re easier to understand
Variety: games that are associated to the lesson; being able to makes notes effectively which help to revise later on.

sec.p: The academic leadership that students welcomed gave them clear explanations of the work, support in understanding when they needed it and a clear structure to their work. The classroom culture that students preferred was a collaborative and trustful one where people could ‘have fun’ while working purposefully. These views echo positively with Lebanese teachers’ claims about how they helped students to engage with learning (Table 6) by being enthusiastic about subject knowledge and energetically interested in helping students to learn through a variety of different activities. They also thought it important to give additional support to students who were struggling to understand an aspect of their work, but their decisions to intervene were based on careful formative assessment of students’ work and progress and a sensitive monitoring of how different students responded to different approaches to learning (Nabhani et al., 2012). Such views bear a strong similarity to the work of Kounin (1970) and Kyriacou (2007) on successful classroom management, studies that span over thirty years between them. They offer an agenda for professional development for teachers whether constructed through their own reflective practice (Schön, 1987) or guided through professional development programmes (Bubb and Earley, 2010) such as IQEA (Hopkins, 2001).

sec.title: Creating cultures of conflict and confrontation
sec.p: If students’ positive perspectives on schooling can offer school leaders at all levels important insights into how to create with students purposeful and successful school learning communities, students’ negative perspectives of schooling and lessons offer teachers and school leaders severe warnings on what needs to be eradicated if schools are to improve. Indeed, the aspects of schooling which students in these studies disliked bear many resemblances to those characteristics related to schools described as ‘stuck’ (Stoll and Seashore Louis, 2007) or ‘failing’ (Ofsted, 2011). Students’ views of what they disliked comes from two of the sites (Tables 9, 10, 11). Aspects of schooling that students disliked reflected their disengagement from the school system, e.g. dislike of certain subjects, annoyance with other students’ anti-social behaviour, such as bullying or shouting, and resentment of some teachers’ behaviours.

caption.p: Lebanese primary school students’ views of what they disliked about schooling

tr.td: Beating by teachers, screaming by teachers, punishment, shouting of students, being beaten by other students, lots of homework, noisy students, being 40 in class, Arabic social studies, class needs painting and better desks.

caption.p: Year 9 English students’ views of what they disliked about schooling

list-item.p: Punitive teachers: has a go at you as soon as you get in the classroom like ‘Can’t sit there − Move away from them’ and when you’re not even doing anything … my maths class [teacher] she’ll put everyone else with their mates … but I’m either on my own or with people I don’t like
Disrespectful teachers: the teachers always used to have a go at me and … some of them really abuse dyslexics … I don’t like teachers that shout a lot … 'cos it makes you feel intimidated and small.

caption.p: Year 9 English students’ views of teacher coercion

list-item.p: One of the Vice Principals stands at the door, making sure everyone’s in their uniform in the morning … everybody’s scared of him 'cos they get yelled at, and really badly. And when he shouts, his voice goes right through you
Sometimes I get earache. She shouts in my ear. At other people and it kills my ear like mad. I like it when she’s calmed down – when she’s not angry with other people
I don’t like DT. The teacher’s a bit moody. Different personalities [like] one day she’ll be alright with me but be a bit sarcastic
If I don’t like it, I won’t do it. [Teachers] send me out – tell me off – whatever … other groups, class, seats … It doesn’t really affect me.

sec.p: The last included perceived unfairness by teachers, being treated, as they thought, disrespectfully by teachers or the school, tight or strict control by teachers that ignored students’ agency, and teachers who were perceived as incompetent. Students disliked teachers who made manifest the power they had over them seemingly regardless of students’ rights (Sebba and Robinson, 2011) or of students’ perspectives (voice). Although the English students seemed to accept the disciplinary system in their school, some of them resented the ways it was implemented to try to create docile bodies (Foucault, 1977) by, amongst other things, surveillance of student activity by security cameras, the monitoring of the use of the school toilets (Busher and Cremin, 2012) and punishment that seemed pointless. In particular they resented teachers’ willingness to coerce students by projecting their authority in various ways, such as that of verbal violence (Table 11), a view with which the Lebanese students concurred (Table 9). Whatever form this coercion took, it seemed to lack respect for the students as people and emphasised discipline and control as the main values the schools espoused to meet their performative targets.

sec.title: Students’ views of unsuccessful lessons
sec.p: Not surprisingly, students’ views of unsuccessful lessons (Tables 12 and 13) reflected what they disliked about school: teachers who were perceived as incompetent, either being unable to organise lessons effectively or to work with students successfully, or to make the topic of a lesson intelligible to students. Lack of variety of work during lessons, coupled with a lack of opportunity to take part in discussions also led students to consider lessons unsuccessful. Students’ learning is significantly improved through engagement in group discussions that are focused on aspects of the curriculum (Bennett et al., 2004) especially if they are controversial.

caption.p: Year 9 English students’ views of unsuccessful lessons

list-item.p: Teaching styles: it’s not the actual lessons, it’s just the way that they’re taught … really boring … the [teachers] just repeat themselves a and then it just confuses you
Lack of variety: We just have to sit there and write down everything the teachers tell you to write down – at least two pages
Lack of collaboration: in that lesson we have to be quiet while we’re doing our work and you just can’t talk or nothing
Perceived work overload: I get loads of homework [in science] and in maths
Fear of punishment: if I don’t get [homework] in I get detention or something and that’s what worries me. I don’t really like getting detentions.

caption.p: Year 9 Science students’ views of unsuccessful lessons

list-item.p: Too much to take in: certain things are very hard to understand meaning that it can put you off; sometimes, we get overpowered with information
Too much theory/writing: sometimes a specific topic can be very theory based; I don’t like lots of theory work
Poor teaching: when we have supply teachers. They don’t have a clue about what to do; it can be tedious, and I don’t always learn that way
Other: seating plan.
Some topics: I find them hard to grasp
Social aspects: she cannot control our class: I end up teaching myself out of a book

Teachers’ approaches to teaching: she just makes us copy things off the board which isn’t helping at all; one of my teachers doesn’t explain anything so I don’t understand; poor teaching material; teachers are unorganised
Too much writing/theory: being left to read textbooks: too much information/theory.

sec.p: The foregoing discussion offers an agenda for professional development whether constructed through teachers’ own reflective practice (Schön, 1987) or guided by senior or middle leaders through professional development programmes (Bubb and Earley, 2010) to change the confrontational and resistant cultural values and practices being implemented and to search for strategies to avoid them.

sec.title: Conclusion
sec.p: From the preceding discussion and evidence of students as expert witnesses of schools, teachers and teaching several important implications emerge for leadership in schools, whether at whole school, subject or key stage area, or classroom level.

list-item.p: First, listening to the multiplicity of student voices (Arnot and Reay, 2007) will help schools to improve their practice (Fielding, 2004; Mujis et al., 2005) if only to meet the performative demands made of them (Troman et al., 2007). Capturing the multiplicity of student voice, by school council, year group council, or in each classroom may be difficult, as the Lebanese teachers testify (Table 6). Doing so, however, results in enthusiastic and engaged students who enjoy learning. This, itself, makes easier classroom and school management and helps students and schools, even in economically and socially disadvantaged areas, to gain a wide range of achievements.

Second, student perspectives on schooling help teachers to reflect on their own practices (McIntyre et al., 2005) and can help senior and middle level leaders identify programmes of professional development that will help staff and students to work together more collaboratively and successfully.

Third, student voices raise challenging questions about what are appropriate cultures for schools, but seem to indicate particular cultures that closely resemble those associated with improving schools (Hopkins, 2001; Stoll and Seashore Louis, 2007). This culture is founded on values of mutual respect and collaboration between teachers and students, of the sort found in Rights Respecting Schools (Sebba and Robinson, 2011), and is central to students’ successful learning (Hopkins, 2001) and the development of their understandings of citizenship for a democratic society (Potter, 2002; Clough and Holden, 2002).

Fourth, and perhaps most challengingly to leaders in schools and classrooms, recognition that students have a legitimate voice demands that students are respected as people, not merely as units of output by which to measure school performance. As participating members of a school community and the various learning communities in it, students have part-ownership of it and a respected and acknowledged part to play in negotiating its culture and practices along with the teachers, support staff and other stakeholders in it. This implies that staff have to work with students as fellow members of these learning communities (Bolam et al., 2005) in schools and classrooms despite the asymmetrical power relationships between them. It leads to a positive view of democratic schooling (Woods, 2005; Woods and Gronn, 2009; Fielding, 2011) focused on leadership, trust and respect, serving purposeful collaborative communities whose members pursue the construction of learning together.
